I, by which Michael and Walter de Morton, the lords, grant to Robert, son of Hugh de Orsolooue, common pasture in the fee of Morton for all kinds of animals, as marked by boundaries (which are specified) for 25 years, paying 6d. annually, and giving 20s. for entrance. MS. Ch. Staffs. 31.

James, son of Reginald de Morton, grants to Michael, son of William de Morton, the whole of his part which lie has in 'le Polsiche' to make a fish-pond, with the whole reflow of water and sufficient land for the same, for which the said Michael gives the whole of his part which he has in a certain meadow called 'le Hokmedue,' near the water-mill of Morton, and half a mark. (1260.) Witn. sir William de Cavershwalle, sheriff of Staffordshire and Salop, etc. MS. Ch. Staffs. 32.

John, son of Michael de Morton, grants to Robert, son of Richard de Wilbruyghton, for his life a messuage and land adjoining that which William del Brok held in the fee of Morton, and one acre of meadow in Brademedewe, paying annually 3s., with a cok and a hen and a pennyworth of bread at Christmas, and ten eggs at Easter. (c. 1300.) MS. Ch. Staffs. 33.

John de Moreton grants to Robert Brydd of Orselowe and Matilda his wife the whole part of one meadow which he has in Moreton in the new meadow which is called 'le Turnymersche,' for the term of their lives. Dated at Moreton the Thursday next after the feast of the apostles SS. Peter and Paul, 10 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Staffs. 34.

Thomas Foster of Salforde, co. Bedford, in part fulfilment of a certain Chancery decree dated 3 July, Trinity term last, grants to Edmund Pedder and Thomas Crosse the whole of his manor of Moreton in co. Stafford, in trust for him, his wife Elizabeth and his heirs. Dated 26 October, 1 Q. Mary. MS. Ch. Staffs. 35.

Thomas Foster de Salford, co. Beds, esq., in part fulfilment of a certain Chancery decree dated 3 July, Trinity term last, grants to Edmund Pedder and Thomas Cross the whole of his manor of Morton in Staffordshire, in trust for him, his wife Elizabeth and his heirs. Dated 27 February, 7 Ed. VI. MS. Ch. Staffs. 36.

Edward Lewson of Perton, esq., Robert Eyton of Donnyngton, Salop, esq., and Thomas Wyke of Pryors Lee, Salop, gent., grant to George Forster of Ivelith, esq. the whole of their manor of Morton in the county of Stafford. Dated 20 May, 2 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Staffs. 37.

(Shropshire) NEWTOWNE, WOLVERLEY, and NORTHWOOD. Deed of consecration of a churchyard adjoining the chapel of Newtown of the B. K. Charles the Martyr by John, bp. of Lichfield and Coventry, for the hamlets of Newtowne, Wolverley, and Northwood. Dated at Newtowne, 7 June, 1665. MS. Ch. Staffs. 38.

RAKEDALE (Leicestershire). Inrolment of pleadings in a suit tried Trinity term, 2 Henry V, by which the prior and convent of Canwell recover from sir Ralph Shirley, kt., their right of presentation to the church of Rakedale. MS. Ch. Staffs. 20.
RONTON. Edward Doyle, esq., grants to John Harecourt and others his manor of Ronton in co. Stafford. Dated 24 March, 30 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Staffs. 39.

RUGELEY. Richard de Puteo of Rugeleye grants to Robert ad fontem of Wlseleye, for his homage and service and half a mark of silver, four 'seillions' of his land in the fields of Ruggele, paying annually to him and his heirs one penny, (c. 1240-50.) [With seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 48.

SANDWELL (Priory of). Richard N..(?) of Little B[arr] grants to the church of S. Mary Magd. and monks of Sondwell, in frankulmoigne, a certain part of his land to increase the land of the said monks. (c. 1240-50.) MS. Ch. Staffs. 40.

STANLOWE. William, son of Robert Avenel of Midilton, grants to William, son of Milo de Siverhul, the whole of his land which he has at Stanlowe in the territory of Midilton, Caldalowe and elsewhere, saving the dowry of his mother "Dyonisie"; paying annually one penny, (c. 1270-80.) MS. Ch. Staffs. 42.

STOKE DOYLEY (Northamptonshire). Margaret, daughter of the late Edward Doily, grants to Egelina, who was the wife of sir John Bagod of Bromleygh Bagod, kt., for her life, all her lands and tenements in Stokedoily which she had of the gift and feoffment of the said Egelina. Dated at Stoke Doiley the Monday next after the feast of St. Barnabas the apostle, 47 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Staffs. 43.

SUTTON. Indenture by which Hugh, the prior, and convent of St. Giles, Canwell, demise to Richard Turnour of Sutton Perecourt two cottages in Sutton with a croft and 3 acres called Foxland for 80 years, at an annual rent of 3s. Dated at Canwell, 8 October, 16 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Staffs. 22.

TAMWORTH. Indenture made 24 June, 15 Edw. IV?, by which the prior and convent of Canwall demise to Roger Browne of Thamworth, fuller, a mill for 30 years at an annual rent of 13s. 4d. [Mutilated.] [English] MS. Ch. Staffs. 24.

TRENTHAM (Priory of). Bond given by Nicholas, the prior, and the convent of Trentham to Thomas de Schelton for payment of a loan of 10 marks. Dated at Trentham the Wednesday next before the feast of the Purification of the B. V. M., 1382. MS. Ch. Staffs. 44.

WALTON upon TRENTE. Indenture of a lease made the ... of November, 8 Charles I, between Thomas Donne of Donne, co. Stafford, and ... of the one part, and Robert Donne of Walton upon Trente, yeoman, of the other part. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 45.

WEFORD and HASTAY. Thomas, the prior, and convent of Canewell remit and quit-claim to sir William de Oddyngeseles, kt., a certain old ditch which divides his park of Woford and their wood of Hastay, for exchange of lands and tenements between their house of Canwell on the one part, and sir Ralph de Lymeseye and the lady Joan de Hoddyngeseles of the other, provided that neither party shall be able to claim anything from the other by reason of the ditch. Dated at Weford the day of Conception of the B. V. M., 23 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Staffs. 17.
STAFFORD and DERBY. Roll of five membranes of rents belonging to the crown in the counties of Stafford and Derby, unpaid in 1654, from 1647. MS. Rolls Staffs. 1.

TUTBURY HONOR, &c. Roll of 4 membranes containing (1) arrears of rent on the account of Thomas Gell, receiver of the rents &c. for the honor of
Tutbury, due in 1650; (2) arrears in 1652 of rents of chauntries in the counties of Stafford and Derby; (3) arrears of rents in 1650 of possessions of the duchy of Lancaster in the same counties attested by Thomas Hanson, deputy auditor. MS. Rolls Staffs. 2,

ABINGER alias ABINWORTH and OCKLEY. Indenture (dated 1703) by which Thomas Wakeham of Wotton, co. Surrey, yeoman, guardian to John Wakeham of Abinger, demises to Thomas Lipscombe a messuage, barn, land, &c. in the parishes of Abinger and Ockley, co. Surrey, for 2 years, at an annual rent of Â£30. MS. Ch. Surrey 1.

ALDERBURY and ALSTED, WISBUBGH, &c. Charter (with a deed annexed) by which John Ireland, sen., of Wisborow Grene grants to John Aleyn, gent., and others, all his lands &c. in Aldebury and Alfolde, co. Surrey, and in Wiseburgh Grene and Kyrdeforde, co. Sussex, to hold the same to the uses mentioned in his annexed deed of feoffment. Dated 12 January, 20 Hen. VIII. English (feoffment) and Latin (grant) MS. Ch. Surrey 2.

ASHER. Indenture made 8 July, 13 Charles II, by which queen Henrietta Maria and others, in consideration of the receipt Â£80, demise to John Bird, citizen and goldsmith of London, and Solomon Seabright, a messuage and land at Asher in the co. of Surrey, for 60 years, at an annual rent of Â£3 13s. 4d. [Signed by the Queen, Kenelm Digby, and others.] [Engraved portrait of the Queen in the initial letter.] MS. Ch. Surrey 3.

BERMONDSEY. Significat to the crown for the arrest and imprisonment of Susan Cooper, of the parish of Bermondsey, ... communicated for contumacy, in not appearing to answer the complaint of Rebecca Robinson for defamation. [1702-06.] MS. Ch. Surrey 23.

CARSHALTON. Fine levied at Westminster, 2 William and Mary, by which Walter Rumsey and Sarah his wife acknowledge the right of Henry Dyne, jun., to a messuage, dovecote, &c. in Carshalton, for which recognition the said Henry gave to the said Walter Â£100 sterling. MS. Ch. Surrey 4.

CHELESHAM. William de Watevill demises to John de Immeworth the whole of his land in Chelesham for 12 years, at an annual rent of 100s. from the feast of Purification of M. 18 Hen. III. [Mutilated] MS. Ch. Surrey 5.

CHOBHAM. An award of Laurence Stoughton and Olliphe Leighe, esqrs., for the settlement of disputes between John Heywood, clerk, vicar of Chobham, and Thomas Wye alias Wyth of Chobham, and Edmond Hedge alias Hedger of Cheryton, concerning the right to certain lands in Chobham. Dated 21 August, 33 Elizabeth. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 6.

CROYDON. Indenture dated 8 July, 1689, by which William, archbishop of Canterbury, demises to Jacob Hampson of Mitcham, Surrey, gent., his lodge or park house in the parish of Croydon and other lands, to hold the same for 21 years, at an annual rent of Â£100. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 7.
Will and probate of Mary Banks of Croyden, Surrey. Will dated 8 June, 1703. Probate dated 11 January, 1704. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 8.

DUNTESFOLD. Gilibert de Merkewyke grants to John, son of Henry de Anekekaappe, for 14s. a messuage with a curtilage which Hawisia de la Gate formerly held in Duntesfold, lying in the place called la Hokeggate at an annual rent of 12d. of silver. Dated at Merkewyke the Monday next before Hokeday, 10 Ed. I. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Surrey 9.

EWELL. Award of the arbitrators (Edmond Slyfelde and John Skynner, esquires) in a matter of dispute between Elizabeth Hoorde, widow of Edmund Hoord, and Saunder Braye, concerning the right to certain lands in Ewell. Dated 19 July, 25 Q. Elizabeth. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 10.
Probate, from the Prerogative Court, of the nuncupative will of Allan Hoorde of Ewell, co. Surrey, dated 23 May, 1603. MS. Ch. Surrey 11.
The declaration of nuncupatio will of Allen Hoord of Ewell, gentleman. [Not dated.] MS. Ch. Surrey 12.
FARNHAM. Will of Richard Fox of Farnham, tallow-chandler, made 5 July, 1670. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 13.

HORSEY DOWNE. Indenture made 2 November, 8 James I, by which William Weldon of Shottisbrooke, co. Berks, and Margaret his wife sell to Robert Hobart of Cliffordes Inne, London, gent., certain messuages, lands, &c. in Horsey downe, known by the name of Purveys rents, for 99 years, at a pepper-corn rent. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 14.

Indenture made 12 July, 8 Charles I, by which Thomas Weldon of Braye, co. Berks, son and heir of Edward Weldon, esq., deceased, demises to Raphe Stafferton of Horsey downe, esq., a messuage called Horsseyrlowne house in Horsseydowne, for 60 years after the decease of dame Isabell Nevill, his mother, now wife of sir Thomas Nevill, at an annual rent of Â£5. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 15.

IWOOD, in the parish of NYDGATE. Indenture made 13 December, 10 Elizabeth (reciting a former indenture), by which Thomas Collette, citizen and merchant of London, in consideration of the receipt of Â£500, sells and assigns to John Heathe of King's Lynne, esquire, all his right and title in certain houses, iron works,
&c. in Iwood or Iwoode parke, in the parish of Nudygate alias Nydgate. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 16.

LAMBETH. Indenture, being an award by Philip Skippon, Edmund Harby, Franc. Allein, Richard Salwey, John Jones, and Thomas Browne in a suit at law between Thomas Scott of Lambeth, esq., and Matthew Hardy of Lambeth, gent., concerning the division of the manor of Lambeth and the lands thereunto belonging, and also of Lambeth palace and its appurtenances. Dated 6 June, 1649. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 17.
MORTLAKE. License by Thomas Rives, as dean of Shoreham and Croydon, of Thomas Foxley to the curacy of the chapel of Mortlake. Dated 4 October, 1631. MS. Ch. Surrey 18.

Indenture made 27 May, 1658, by which right hon. John Lambertof Wimbledon, Surrey, and dame Frances his wife and others, covenant with John East of Gabriell Fanchurch, London, merchant, to levy a fine, before the feast of the nativity of St. John B., of and for certain messuages and lands situate in Mortlake, Surrey. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 19.
OCKHAM. Will of John Weston the Elder, of Ockham, co. Surrey, gent., dated 10 August, 1590. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 20.

SOUTHWARK. Indenture made 8 September, 37 Hen. VIII, by which Edward Weldyn of Suthwerk, esq., demises to John Cater, citizen and vintner of London, a garden platt and a house in the parish of St Olaf, Southwark for 50 years, at an annual rent of 26s. 8d. [English] [Fragment of seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Surrey 21.

Petition of Matthew Hardy of London, shaper, John Michell of Southwark, carpenter, and Richard Walcott of Lambeth, co. Surrey, yeoman, to the lords commissioners of the great seal, and the issue of a commission under the great seal directed to George Cotton, esq. and four others in the matter of the bankruptcy of Daniel Gotherston of Southwark and Francis Soane, late of Newington, chapmen. Dated 22 April, 1651. [With great seal "in the first yeare of fredome by Gods blessing restored 1648".] [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 22a.

Indenture made 26 September, 1649, by which sir John Wollaston and other persons, entrusted with the lands of the archbishops and bishops by Parliament, in consideration of the receipt of Â£4380 8s. 3d., sell to Thomas Walker of Camberwell, Surrey, gentleman, the Manor of Southwark, part of the possessions of the Bishop of Winchester. [English] MS. Ch. Surrey 22b.

John de Twynem, receiver of the moneys of John de Britan, earl of Richemunde, in the barony of Hastyng, acknowledges to have received of John Fillol and William de Northo, assigned to collect and levy the scutage in the counties of Surrey and Sussex, the sum of Â£24 18s. 0d., for the 31st and 34th years of Ed. I. Dated at the Chamber "la Chaumbre" in the parish of Tycheshurst, Monday on the vigil of St. Thomas Apost., 10 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Surrey 24.

TANREGG AND WOLKNOSTED. William le Halere remits and quit-claims to Richard Corbyn and Agnes his wife, all his right in all those lands and tenements which the said Richard and Agnes have by the gift and feoffment of John Cokeman at 'le Feldbregg' in the parish of Tanregg and Wolknestede. Dated at Est Grensted, Septuagesima Sunday ("die dominica Carniprivii" [Quincquagesima Sunday?]), 29 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Surrey 25.

WINDLESHAM. Richard, son and heir of William Pendere of Bakgeschoteford in the parish of Wyndlesham, husbandman, grants to John Martyn one parcel of land lying there, called Smythshawe. Dated at Bakgeschoteford, 12 April, 37 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Surrey 26.

John Frampton and Margaret his wife grant to John Martyn of Bagshote and Joan his wife, all their lands and tenements which they acquired of Richard Pendere in Bagshote, together with certain other land acquired of John Huntle and John Denton in the same village. Dated at Bagshote, 28 Nov., 12 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Surrey 27.
ST. MARY'S, NEWINGTON. Chancery decree dated 21 July, 1729, in a cause, Abraham Annesley and Margaret his wife, one of the daughters of Richard Giles, against Giles. MS. Rolls Surrey 1.

ALCESTER. John Fremon and Alice his wife, daughter of John Cokkys of Alncestre, by their charter confirmed to William Botreaux the whole of a messuage in Peggyslond, the said William now wills that if the said John and Alice pay l0s. within three years, the said messuage shall revert to them. Dated the Saturday next before the feast of St. Faith, virgin, 7 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Warwick. 1.

ARELEYE. John, son and heir of the late Peter de Lymesi, quit-claims to sir Richard de Egebaston, kt., the occupier and farmer of the manor of Areleye, from the feast of St. Michael, 19 Ed. II, to the date of this present charter, all claim for waste, &c. in the said manor. Dated at Covintre the Monday next after the feast of SS. Perpetua and Felicia, 19 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Warwick. 2.
ATHERSTON. View of frankpledge with court of John Langeley , esq., lord of the manor of Athereston, held the Saturday next before the feast of St. Thomas, 19 Dec., 29 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Warwick. 3.

BEREFORD, &c. Letters patent of King Edward III, dated at Westminster 6 Feb., 29 of his reign, making known, that, by an inspection of the rolls of Chancery it appears that with the assent of Bartholomew de Burgherssh and Elizabeth his second wife, of Mark Husee and Margery his third wife, and Isabella who was the wife of Henry de Ferrars, the fourth of the daughters and heirs of Theobald de Verdon, deceased, who held of the King Edw. II in capite of the fees and parts of knights' fees and the advowsons of churches which were the said Theobald's have been assigned to Thomas, son and heir of Joan, who was the wife of Thomas de Furnivall, the eldest of the daughters and heirs of the said Theobald, according to the law and custom of England, the underwritten fees and advowsons, viz. in demesne four knights' fees in Potteleye, Cheynestre, Strote, Twyldenhyde, Est Heche, and Walnesthorp, which Richard Comyn and the heirs of William Comyn had, the fourth part of one knight's fee in Aleton which Robert Brown holds, the half of one knight's fee in Mousleye, which the heirs of Richard Faype holds, the half of one knight's fee in Webbeton, Cobbewell, Walshopthorn, and Meere, which Roger and George Crikentot hold, the half of one knight's fee in Rouleston, which pertains to the castle of Ewyas in Herefordshire, one knight's fee in Hopton Caudinant in co. Salop, which John de Hopton holds the half of one knight's fee in Neuhall, co. Derby, which the heirs of Robert de la War... holds, one knight's fee in Northbur, co. Stafford, which Ralph de Botiler holds the half of one knight's fee in Bereford, co. Warwick, which John de Napfold holds, the half of one knight's fee in Lullyngton in the same county, which the heir of Peter de Walwardyngton holds, and the reversion of two knights' fees, the half of a knight's fee and a fourth part in Pyonia and Houton Cotes in co. Hereford, which Richard de la Lynde, jun., Philip Aphowel and Rees Aphowel hold, one knight's fee in Thurlaston, co. Warwick, which Simon fitz Margery and John Darset hold, a fourth part in Morton, the half of
one knight's fee in Hopton and Alverton, co. Warwick, which the free tenants there hold to have the same after the death of Elizabeth de Burgh, who holds the same in dowry after the death of the aforesaid Theobald formerly her husband, together with the advowson of the church of Neubold and the third presentation to the church of Boseworth, co. Leicester, the advowson of moiety of the priory of Lantony in Wales, and the reversion of the advowson of Farnham, co. Bucks. [With fragment of Great seal.] MS. Ch. Warwick. 4.

BURTON HASTINGS. Licence from Brownlow, bp. of Lichfield and Coventry, to John Liptrott, clerk, for performing the office of curate in the church of Burton Hastings, as perpetual curate of the parish. Dated at Eccleshall, 23 Aug. 1773. [Printed form, filled up in MS.] MS. Ch. Warwick. 5.

COLLESHULL, &c. John de Clynton, lord of Maystoke, quitclaims to sir Peter de Monteforti all right in that manor called Kyngeshurst in the co. of Warwick, also in messuages, lands, &c. in the villages of Colleshull, Bromwych, and Sheldon, which the said Peter holds by demise of William de Wotton; and also in all those messuages, curtilages, &c. which the said Peter has by the gift of Simon de Sekkyndone, parson of the church of Thorp Costantyn in Colleshull and Sheldon. Dated at Colleshull the Wednesday next after the feast of SS. Simon and Jude, 28 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Warwick. 6.

COVENTRY, &c. Henry d'Aubeny (de Albiniaco), son of Henry D'Aubeny (de Albiniaco), of Wycheford, and Christiana his wife give and confirm to Geoffrey de Langele and Matilda his wife and their heirs, all their capital messuage of mill Coventry together with rents, &c., the mills of Hyssel, and lands, rents and services in Coventre, with husbote and heybote in the woods of Coventre, Stok, Keresle, and Alspathe, with the reversion of other lands in the same villages; for which the said Geoffrey gives 85 shillings worth of land in several places, and released the father of the grantor from prison at New Sarum by paying 140 marks for him to Robert de Totenhale. (c. 1244-50.) [Geoffrey de Langele was dead in 1274.] [With seal of Henry "Daube...".] MS. Ch. Warwick. 7.

Bond given by Richard Palmer and Elizabeth his wife of Coventry to John Sneyd, barbor, in Â£20 with regard to the sale of a messuage in the Crossechepyng in the "cetie" of Coventry. Dated 20 June, 35 Hen. VIII. [English] MS. Ch. Warwick. 8.

Indenture made 25 Feb., 24 Chas. II, by which Samuell Baron, citizen and lynnendraper of London, in consideration of a sum of Â£45 grants to John Hunt of Coventry, shoemaker, a messuage in Coventry in a place called Croscheaping. [English] MS. Ch. Warwick. 9.

ERDYNGTON. Henry Tymmen of Erdyngton grants to John his son a certain plot of meadow in the fee of Erdyngton, in the meadow called 'Assalt,' and five sellions in Tymmecroft. Dated at Erdyngton the Monday next after the feast of St. Edith, 15 Ed. III MS. Ch. Warwick. 10.
GRENEBERUE. William de Harecurt, son of Robert de Harecurt, grants to William Pat two of his villeins and land in Greneberue. (c. 1280.) MS. Ch. Warwick. 11.
SHUCBURGH. William ... grants to Wibert West, esq., James ... and theirs a tenement in Shucburgh. Dated at Shucburgh, 20 Edw. IV. [In great part illegible.] MS. Ch. Warwick. 12.

WARWICK. Thomas Yonge, dean of St. Mary's, Warwick, John, prior of the church of the Holy Sepulchre, John Hedham, master of the hospital of St. John, and Robert Wylarsay, vicar of St. Nicholas, appoint John Derlyng their proctor to act for them. Dated at Warwick, 10 March, 1420. MS. Ch. Warwick. 13.

Appointments of Henry Delves , esq., and Timothy St. Nicholas, esq., as justices of the peace for the county of Warwick, with the oaths for the same appointments. Dated at Westminster, 13 Nov., 10 George I. MSS. Ch. Warwick. 14-19.

WASPERTON. Indenture made 9 March, 1744, being a lease from John Tabor, gent. and Amy his wife, widow of Thomas Rawlinson, deceased, and Richard Rawlinson, LL.D., to John Seely Oldham, yeoman, of a messuage or farm called Heathcott in Wasperton, in the occupation of James Lunn, for 21 years, at an annual rent of Â£160 to the said John and Amy, and to the said Richard one chine of bacon.
MS. Ch. Warwick. 20.

WEDINGTON. Notarial instrument by which William Hudson, clerk, notary public, attests the resignation of William Stawnton of the church of Wedyngton, made in a parlour ["parlora"] within the dwelling of Christopher Bromeborugh at Coventry. Dated 1458, 8 July.
MS. Ch. Warwick. 21.

ROWINGTON. View of frank-pledge and court baron of the lady Anne, countess of Warwick, widow, held at Rowington, 3 May, 38 Elizabeth, before John Huggeford, esq., seneschal, and Thomas Michell, gent., sub-seneschal. MS. Rolls Warwick. 1.

ROWINGTON. The same as MS. Rolls Warwick., 2: View of frank-pledge and court baron of the lady Anne, countess of Warwick, widow, held at Rowington, 3 May, 38 Elizabeth, before John Huggeford, esq., seneschal, and Thomas Michell, gent., sub-seneschal. MS. Rolls Warwick. 2.
KIRKBY-STEPHEN. Presentation by Philip, lord Wharton, of Francis Higgenson to the rectory of Kirkby-Stephen, vacant by the death of the last incumbent. Dated 22 Sept. 1654. MS. Ch. Westmorland 1.
NATEBY. Charters (inrolled) of grants of lands, woods, &c. in the village of Nateby. [Roll written temp. Hen. VI or Edw. VI.] MS. Rolls Westmorland 1
(a) William, son of Elyas de Nateby, grants to sir Michael de Hartla all his lands and tenements in the village and field of Nateby, with all the appurtenances.

(b) Roger de Clifford, jun., Isabel his wife, Roger de Leyburn and Idonea his wife, grant to sir Michael de Hartla a certain vaccary in their forest of Mallyestang which is called Snetwayt, at an annual rent of 6d.

(c) Idonia de Leyburne, widow grants to Michael, lord of Hartecla, a licence to enable him to inclose the woods of Hartecla and Nateby with a hedge or ditch, and to hunt therein, which she has by heirship from her father Robert de Vipount, who was also the father of Isabella wife of Roger de Clyfford.
(d) Part of a grant from King Edward to Thomas Rukby "le unncle" of all the lands and tenements which were Andrew de Hertcla's in the vills of Nateby and Wherton.

(e) Thomas de Rokeby "l'uncle" grants to Richard Roter, vicar of Briniston, all his lands, &c. in the vills of Nateby and Querton, with the third part of the demesne there, also all his lands, &c. in Slegill. Dated at Briniston on the feast of St. Michael, 30 Ed. III.
(f) Thomas de Musgrave grants to sir Michael de Hartcla the homage and service of Thomas, son of John Snodding, for all the lands, &c. he held in Nateby.

(g) Richard Router, master of the hospital of Keprer, grants to sir Thomas de Mussgrave, kt., all the lands, &c. which he has in the villages of Querton and Nateby by the gift of sir Thomas de Rukeby, kt., sen. Dated at London, Wednesday on the feast of St. Leonard, 1364.

BISSHOPSTON. Constat of the exchequer, dated 3 James I, 21 November, that sir Alexander Tutt, kt., sheriff of Wiltshire, has paid of the goods and chattels of Thomas Smythe of Busshopestone, co. Wilts, 100s. MS. Ch. Wilts. 2.

BRUTFORD. John le Foul of Brutford and Joan his wife grant to William le Duyn and Christiana his wife, seven pence annual rent which Thomas Wrench was accustomed to pay for 1 1/2 acre of arable land in the field of Brutford, called Wytheforlang, and which the said Thomas has for his life by demise of Laurence "in the Lane". Dated at Brutford the Tuesday on the feast of St. Matthew, apostle, 6 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Wilts. 3.

John Savage, Robert Porter, capellane, and John Sybsy, grant to Elizabeth, wife of John Park, all lands, &c. which they had of the gift of William Wodehay in Brutford and Stanlich. Dated at Brutford the Saturday after the feast of St. Barnabas, 3 Hen. IV. [Two seals.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 5b.

Henry Not and Agnes his wife, cousin and one of the heirs of William Wodehay, grant to John Park and Elizabeth his wife, all his lands, tenements, &c. which ought to descend to the said Agnes by the death of the said William Wodehay in Brutford. Dated at Brutford the Wednesday next before the feast of St. Dunstan, 3 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Wilts. 4.

Final concord made at Westminster on the octave of the Holy Trinity, 22 Rich. II, by which William Wodehay recognises that a
third part of the manor of Stanlynch and a messuage and 14 acres, of meadow and 16 acres of pasture in Brytford belongs to Agnes, wife of Henry Not. MS. Ch. Wilts. 5a.

CHILTERNE. Letters patent of King Edward VI, dated at Westminster 20 Sept., 1st of his reign, granting various privileges to William Powlet, K.G., Lord St. John, and the manor of Chilterne in Wilts. MS. Ch. Wilts. 6.

CHIPPENHAM. Copy in 15th cent. of decree of Robert de Brantesim [a mistake for Brantestone?], official of Robert, bp. elect of Sarum, concerning the appropriation of the church of Chippenham to the use of the prior and convent of Farleigh, Wilts, and augmenting the vicarage with the tithes of Tyderington, the vicar paying for them 40s. yearly to Farleigh. Dated at Sarum, 16 Kl. May, 1272. MS. Ch. Wilts. 8.
DOUNTON. William Walter of Dounton, co. Wilts, husbandman, grants to Richard Hugyn, esq., all his lands and tenements, &c. in Dounton. Dated at Dounton, 16 October, 30 Hen. VI. MS. Ch. Wilts. 7.

LAVINGTON (Bishops). Fine made at New Sarum on the morrow of St. Michael, 9 Ed. I, by which William, son of Geoffrey le Clerk of Lavynton, acknowledges the right of Robert, bishop of Salisbury and his church, to a messuage, hide, and 19 1/2 acres of land and 12s. annual rents in Lavynton, for which the said bishop paid to the said William 25 marks of silver. MS. Ch. Wilts. 10.
LAVINGTON. Presentation by the dean and chapter of Ch. Ch. of John, to the vacant living of Lavington of Christopher Aborrowe, clerk. Dated 10 April, 9 Elizabeth. MS. Ch. Wilts. 11.
LONGLEAT. Certificate of the appointment of Daniel Tonstall, M.A., as domestic chaplain to the earl of Bath. Dated 1690. [Fine impression of the earl's arms.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 12.

MILDENHALL. Indenture made 29 November, 1727, by which Katherine Pococke of Mildenhall, widow, demises to Ralph Tabor of Mildenhall, yeoman, copyhold estates known as Burgesses in Mildenhall, Playsteed's, Grandie's and Bowsher's for one year, at a rent of Â£50. [The foot of this chirograph is in the P.R.O., Common Pleas, Feet of Fines, Series I (C.P. 25(1)). Case 252 File 24 No 2.] [English] MS. Ch. Wilts. 14.

NETHERAVEN. Fine made at Westminster, 26 Ed. III, and afterward on the quindene of St. Michael an. 28 between John Tot of Netheraven and Alice his wife, plaintiffs, and Roger le Sauser and Joan his wife, defendants, by which the said defendants acknowledge a messuage, 27 acres of land, 1 1/2 acre of meadow, and 20 sheep, in Netheraven, to belong to the said John; and the said plaintiffs quit-claim to the said Roger and Joan all right to a messuage, 20 1/2 acres of land, and 1 acre of meadow. For this quit-claim the said John and Alice gave to Roger and Joan 20 marks of silver. MS. Ch. Wilts. 15.

OKEBOURN (Priory of). A receipt given by Ralph, rector of the church of St. Botulph without Aldrichegate, London, and collector of the annual tenths from the clergy for the king in the diocese of London, to the prior of Okeburn for Â£4 l0s. 2 1/2d., from the church of Ruisshlepe and from Donton, Fordhem, Wodeham Ferrers, etc. Dated London, 6 Feb. 1374. MS. Ch. Wilts. 16.

OXFORD. John, the abbot, and convent of Malmesbury confirm to the prior and convent of the Holy Trinity, Norwich, a certain parcel in Oxford near Stokwelle strete in perpetuity, being a house or chamber built by the said priory with two studies ("studis") annexed, reserving the right of passage for the feeding flocks and cattle for the meadow called Longspoot. Dated at Malmesbury, 20 May, 1472. [Seal broken.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 13.

STANLYNCH. Nicholas le Duyn grants to William le Duyn his brother the whole of two parts of the mill of Stanlinch, and also of the lands of 'La Mule croft' and Battescrofte, and half a virgate of land in Bereford, of which lands Joan, who was the wife of William le Duyn our father, holds the third part in name of dowry. Dated at Stanlynch on the feast of the Trinity, 12 Ed. II. [In the charter the name Duyn has been altered in ink to something like Boykin.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 17.

Nicholas le Duyn and Andrew his brother agree to divide between them two parts of a water-mill in Stanlinch, and 2 parts of 14 1/2 acres of land in Bereford and La Mulecrofte, and 2 parts of a field called Battescrofte, which mill and land William le Duyn the father of the said Nicholas and Andrew gave to them and to Thomas le Duyn (deceased) for their lives, and from which Joan the wife of William holds the third part in the name of dowry. Dated at Stanlinch on the feast of the Nativity of our Lord, 12 Ed. II. [In the charter the name Duyn has been altered in ink to something like Boykin.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 18.

John Columbel, vicar of Brutford, remits and quit-claims to William le Duyn of Stanlynch and Cristina his wife all his right in the half of one piece of ground called 'le Gerdelond.' Dated at Brutford the Tuesday next after the feast of the Ascension of our Lord, 10 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 19.

Sir Thomas Bouklond, kt., grants to John Dekne, clerk, all his lands and tenements in Stanlynch, which John Cok and Stephen Geghe held for their lives, for his life, paying annually for the same 17s. 6d. to the grantor during the life of the latter Dated at Radelynche the Saturday in the feast of St. Barnabas the apostle, 47 Ed. III. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 20.

Power of attorney to John Bereford and John Driwode from sir Thomas de Bouclonde, kt., to deliver seisin to John Dekne, clerk, of all his lands and tenements, &c. in Stanlynch, co. Wilts. Dated at Radelynch the Saturday in the feast of St. Barnabas, 47 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 21.

John Nywe and William Axebrigge, chaplains, grant to Alianor, who was the wife of John Duyn, all lands, &c. in Stanlinche, Brutford, Langeford, and Cherleton, which they had of the feoffment of the said John Duyn, for the term of her life. Dated at Stanlinche the Wednesday next after the feast of St. Dionisius, 48 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 22.

John Duyn grants to sir John Nywe, and sir William Axebrigge,
chaplains, all his lands, rents, tenements, &c. in Stanlynch, Brutford, Langford, and Cherleton. Dated at Stanlynch, Saturday the last day in the month of September, 48 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Wilts. 23.

Quit-claim from sir Thomas de Bouclonde, kt., to John Dekne, by which he remits all his right ... and heirs, &c. to lands in Stanlynch, which the said John lately had from him for the term of the life of the said John, and which John Bouclonde, the grantor's brother acquired from John Glys. Dated at Radelynch, 6 September, 50 Ed. III. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 24.

Robert Stratford remits and quit-claims to John Shawe and Katherine, daughter of John Aignel, all right and claim in certain lands and tenements in Stanlynch and Langford, with which John Aignel had enfeoffed Andrew Stratford, father of the said Robert. Dated 24 April, 4 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Wilts. 25.

Matilda, relict of sir John de Meryet, kt., remits and quit-claims to Thomas de Meryet her son, the whole of the manor of North Stanlynch and Langeford in the co. Wilts, with all lands, &c., to hold the same for ever. Dated at Lopene the Monday next after the feast of St. Scolastica, virgin, 21 Rich. II. [With seal of arms.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 26.

Indenture witnessing that Thomas Meriet and Elianora his wife have demised to John Chapman, chaplain, the whole of a tenement in Stallynch for 40 years at an annual rent of 8s. 9d. Dated at Stallynch, 3 June, 1 Hen. IV. MS. Ch. Wilts. 27.

Thomas Meryet and Alianora his wife grant to John Hugyn all lands and tenements, &c. which were John Aynel's in Stanlynche in co. Wilts, as also all the lands, &c. which they have in North Stanlynche. Dated at Stanlynche, 17 June, 6 Hen. V. MS. Ch. Wilts. 28.

Composition before the bishop of Salisbury between John Whyte, warden of Winchester College, and the fellows of the same, proprietors of the church of Downton, Sarum diocese, and Ralph Lane, vicar of Downton of the one part, and William Grrene, esq., lord of the manor of Stanlynch, of the other part, by which the manor of Stanlynch is charged for tithes of Â£3 6s. 8d. to Winchester College, and Â£1 to the vicar of Downton, the rest of the tithes being assigned to manor for the time being. Dated, Salisbury 8 October, 1549. MS. Ch. Wilts. 29.

Letters patent of King James I, to sir John Rodney, kt., granting to him, in consideration of a payment into the exchequer of 13s. 4d., the goods and chattels of Barbara Buckland, late of St Andrew's Holborn and of Stanelynch a recusant, together with two parts of the manor of Stanlynch, co. Wilts, for 41 years, at an annual rent of 44s. 5 1/2d. Dated at Westminster, 6 March, 8 James I. MS. Ch. Wilts. 30.
Probate of the will of Philip Bocland of Stanlynch, co. Wilts, granted to Maurice Boculand one of the executors. London, 30 May, 1724. MS. Ch. Wilts. 31.
Appointment of Maurice Bockland of Standlinch, co. Wilts, esq., as major of Wilts co. militia and capt. of horse, by Thomas, earl of Pembroke. Dated 20 May, 1689. [English] MS. Ch. Wilts. 32.

STUTESCOMBE (Manor). Memorandum from the court roll of sir Edward Seymour, visc. Beauchamp of the delivery of 2 messuages to William Harres, Elizabeth his wife, and William his son, 18 Sept., 28 Hen. VIII. MS. Ch. Wilts. 33.
SUTTON MANDEVILLE. Drogo Barentyne grants to sir Hugh le Despencer his manor of Sutton Mandeville with the advowson of the church. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Wilts. 34.

TOTHAM (Great) (Essex). John Gwodman of Monks' Farleigh remits and quit-claims to sir John de Lamare, chaplain of Assche, all his right, &c. in land at Great Totham which, they jointly acquired from James Chapman of Totham. Dated at Monks' Farleigh, 12 March, 48 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Wilts. 9.

WILTS. Letters patent of Queen Elizabeth, dated at Westminster, 20 Dec., 39 of her reign, appointing John Dauntesey, esq., sheriff of the county of Wilts. [With seal.] [Belonged to T. Hearne] MS. Ch. Wilts. 1.
ALBORNE. A particular of the manor of Alborne in the county of Wilts, taken in 1683. MS. Rolls Wilts. 1.
KILCULLEN. Receipt for the excise for the town of Kilcullin, co. Kildare to 24 June, 1661, due at 25 Dec. 1663; not signed or completed. MS. Ch. Ir. 5.
KILDARE (County of). Receipt for the inland excise for the county of Kildare from 24 June, 1660 to 24 June, 1661, due at 25 Dec. 1663 amounting to Â£4; not signed or completed. MS. Ch. Ir. 4.

KILKENNY, &c. Receipt for arrears of the Crown quit-rents in the county of Catherlough, Queen's County, and county of the city of Kilkenny, due at Mich. 1668, amounting to Â£67 13. 10; signed by Jo. Champante, dep. receiver, Thomas Kennedy, chamberlain, and Joh. Sergeant, dep. clark of the Pells. Dated 10 Feb., 1675. MS. Ch. Ir. 1.
Admission of Sir Henry Piers, bart., to the freedom of the city of Kilkenny. Dated 28 August, 1702. [With seal, attached on a broad green ribbon.] MS. Ch. Ir. 6.

MEATH (County of). Receipt for various rents from 32 places in the county of Meath for 1 1/2 year ending Michaelmas, 1663, amounting to Â£236 2s. 11 1/2d.; signed by Jo. Champants, dep. receiver MS. Ch. Ir. 7.
NAAS. Receipt for arrears due 25 Dec. 1660 of the excise of Naas in the county of Kildare from 24 June 1660 to 24 June, 1661; amounting to Â£6; not signed or completed. MS. Ch. Ir. 3.

IKEATHY and OUGHTERIN (Baronies of). Receipt for the excise of the above baronies to the 25 Dec., 1663 from 24 June 1660 to 24 June 1661, due at 25 Dec. 1663 amounting to Â£10; not signed or completed. MS. Ch. Ir. 2.
WICKLOW. Receipt given to Thomas Racket of Wicklow for Ireland excise from 24 June 1660 to 24 June, 1663 due 25 Dec., 1663, amounting to 100s.; not signed or completed. MS. Ch. Ir. 8.

List of persons nominated by James, duke of Ormond, as High Sheriffs of the Irish counties, 15 Chas. II (three in each county). Signed by Maur. Eustace, chancellor, lord James Donellan, Jo. Bysse and J. Temple. MS. Rolls Ir. 1.
CRAIL. Grant of the freedom of the Burgh of Craill to Captain John Heathfeild. Dated 3 April, 1654. [With seal (broken and mended) of the borough, on a blue ribbon.] MS. Ch. Scotland 5.

EDINBURGH. Notarial instrument by Henry Strachauchin of the surrender before Thomas Cheisholm one of the bailiffs of Edinburgh of a house and land in Edinburgh on the north of the ... by Katherine sister and heir of the late David Wygholm, the late holder, by exhibition of earth and a stone, and then, by the delivery of the same, of giving seisin to William Mons, and the said Katherine his wife, and their heirs. Dated 24 October, 1497. MS. Ch. Scotland 2

I. "The aith of ilk Burges maid and gewin at his admissionne" into the Burgh of Edinburgh. II. "The aith of ilk Gildbrother maid and gewin at his admissionne". III. The admission of James Fleyming, son of the late Thomas Fleyming, merchant, into the same Burgh, 13 March, 22 James VI, [1589]. MS. Ch. Scotland 3.
KIRKCALDIE. Admission of Colonel Charles Fairfax to the freedom of the borough of Kirkcaldie. Dated 19 October, 1652. [With seal, broken.] MS. Ch. Scotland 6.

ST. ANDREW (University of). Copy of the diploma 11 June, 1753 for the degree of ... granted by the University of St. Andrew's to William Cowper, M.A.; attested as a true copy by William Falconer of Chester. Roger Comberback, protonotary of the county, Thomas Hayes, M.D. fellow of Pembrok Hall, Cambridge, and Edward Roberts, dep. Registrar of the diocese of Chester. MS. Ch. Scotland 4.

TORPHICHEN (House of St. John of Jerusalem at). Philip de Carriber, son and heir of Adam Manclerc of Carriber, grants to the Hospital of St. John of Jerusalem of Thorphyen in frankalmoigne an annual rent of 2s. from his land of Carriber and one mark as his death and at that of each of his heirs, in name of a third part of his goods. (The grantor, and all the witnesses except three are found signing the Rageman Roll in 1296). (c. 1290-1300.) MS. Ch. Scotland 1.

ASAPH (St.). Copy of a commission of Henry, bishop of St. Asaph, directed to John Stanny and Robert Holbeche, chaplain, his commisaries general in the deaneries of Marchia Myznat, and 7 others. Dated 23 Feb., 1523. MS. Ch. Denbighshire 1.
Letter of orders of Edward Pugh deacon by Edward [Welshpool], bishop of St. Asaph. Dated at Pola, 20 Sept., 1702. MS. Ch. Denbighshire 2.
BANGOR DIOCESE. Constat from the Pipe-office for the first payment of a subsidy due 1st December, 1629. Paid, 1st May, 1630. MS. Ch. Caernarvonshire 1.
Constat from the Pipe-office for the second payment of the third subsidy due ist June, 1630. MS. Ch. Caernarvonshire 2.
CAERNARVONSHIRE. Commission of Peace for the county of Caernarvon. Dated at Westminster, 23 June, 43 George III. MS. Ch. Caernarvonshire 3.

GLAMORGANSHIRE. Writ from Hugh le Despenser, "le fuiz", to John Ingge, sheriff of Glamorganshire, commanding him to accept Â£20 in full satisfaction of Â£80 for a trespass committed by John le Butoillier and Aleyn de Veil Chastel. Dated at St. Brevel, 5 May, 14 Ed. II. [French] MS. Ch. Glamorgan 7.
LLANDRINDOD. Plaint of Walter Thomas, clerk, against James Davies, gent., for a debt of Â£20. Dated Trin. Term, 3rd William and Mary. MS. Ch. Radnorshire 1.

Names returned to the Lords of the Council for the counties of Glamorgan, Brecknock, and Radnor, to serve the office of High Sheriff, 16 Dec. 1697; with the appointment of Lemuel Lloyd to be High Sheriff of Radnorshire in the room of Thomas Williams, deceased. Dated 7 July, 1698. Both signed by Somers, S.Ch. MS. Ch. Radnorshire 2b.

MOLD. Indenture made 13 April, 5th Chas. I, by which Henry, earl of Huntingdon, &c. and Elizabeth his wife, covenant within one year to convey to Henry Hastings, of Donnington Park,
esq., their son, the rectory of Mould in Flintshire, to the use of the said Henry Hastings for ever. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Flintshire 1.

Indenture made 20 May, 12th Charles I, by which Henry Hastings and Ferdinand Hastings, in consideration of the receipt of Â£500, mortgage to Mathew Davis, of Shaston, co. Dorset, esq., the moiety of the parsonage of Mould for 99 years, commencing after the death of Alice Countess of Derby, at a peppercorn rent, as security for payment of a sum of Â£520 upon the 22nd of November next. MS. Ch. Flintshire 2.

ACTON SCOTT. Terrier and note of all the glebe lands, houses and buildings belonging to the rectory or parsonage of Acton Scott alias Acton upon the hill, made and taken 4 May, 5 James I, by the churchwarden sydemen and others the parishioners whole names (10) are hereunto subcribed. MS. Ch. Salop. 94.

BURWARDSLEY. Thomas Clerke of Wenloke grants to William Clerke his son the whole of a tenement and land called Chyldeswodelond, within the lordship of Burwardsley. Dated at Burwardsley the Monday next before the feast of the Invention of the Holy Cross, 26 Hen. VI. [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Salop. 95.

GROTYNGTON. Indenture witnessing that Thomas Farnecote, clerk, and William, vicar of the church of Long Stanton, grant to John Daras and Juliana his wife, and to Roger their son, an annual rent of Â£40 going out of the manors of Grotyngton, Weston, Stowe, and Kenley in the county of Salop, and Hampton Bonet in the county of Worcester, upon certain conditions expressed. Dated the Tuesday next before the feast of St. Hilary at Williley, 22 Rich. II. French MS. Ch. Salop. 96.

Appointment by the Parliamentary Committee of Salop of Leighton Owen to the captaincy of a troop of 60 (besides officers) horse raised as volunteers for the defence of the county. Dated 7 August, 1646. Signed by Thomas Niccolls, H. Mackworth, Andrew Lloyd, Robert Charlton, and Robert Clive. MS. Ch. Salop. 97.

GLASTONBURY. Public notarial instrument by Robert Toneys, clerk, of the election of Richard Whiting, chamberlain, as abbot of the monastery of the B.V.M. of Glastonbury, vacant by the death of Richard Beer. Dated 3 March, 1524 at York Place, Westminster. Present Sir Richard Wyngfeld, K.G., Sir Thomas Moore, Sir Thomas Denys, knts., William Benet, LL.D., Stephen Gardyner, LL.D. MS. Ch. Somerset 51.

BERLESTON. Humphrey, earl of Stafford and lord of Tonbrygge and of Caus, commands receiver general, and his former bailiff or minister of his manor and lordship of Berleston to pay to Edward Doly and Anne his wife an annuity of Â£10 from the profits of the said manor, in pursuance of a grant made by him to them, 31 Dec. 3 Hen. VI. Dated at Hull, 12 January, 3 Hen. VI. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 49.

BISSHEBURY. William de Worlascroft, vicar of Bisshebury, and William de Wybaston, chaplain, grant to Thomas Underhull of Bisshebury and Elena his wife with remainder to their son John, one messuage and certain lands and tenements in Bisshebury, which they had by feoffment of the said Thomas, excepting a garden and cottage adjacent which were formerly Richard Underbill's, and a croft and garden formerly William de Bokyngham's. Dated at Bisshebury the Sunday next after the feast of St. James, apostle, 42 Ed. III. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 50

BROMLEY ABBOTS. John de Hampton, vicar of Bromley Abbots, and Thomas Graunger, chaplain, grant to John de Henleye a messuage with a curtilage adjacent in Bromley Abbots, also they grant to the aforesaid John de Benlye (sic) all the lands and tenements in 'Le Thornyhull' which they had by feoffment of William Grym. Dated at Bromley Abbots the Tuesday next after the feast of St. Michael, 2 Rich. II. [With two small seals.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 51.

BROMLEY. Thomas Kynneresley of Loxley, in co. Stafford, esq., and John Kyrrensby and John Fowle, gentlemen, in performance of the last will of Emota Stanlowe, deceased, remit and quit-claim to Richard Stanlowe all right in a burgage or messuage in Bromley, and appoint Thomas Crosse, sen., their attorney to give seisin. Dated at Bromley on the vigil of St. John the Baptist, 22 Hen. VIII. [With one small seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 52.

COKESLONE. William, son of Richard de Harecurt, grants to Gilbert Reyner of Stafford three virgates of land in Cokeslone, paying annually 12d. of silver. (c. 1260-70.) [Richard H. died in 1258] [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 53.

[CROKESDENE,] and all abbeys &c. of the Cistercian order. Bull of Pope Innocent [IV], granting to the queen of Henry III [Eleanor], the privilege of entering the abbeys and monasteries of the Cistercian order with her attendants, and spending the night there, notwithstanding the statutes of the order. Dated at Lyons, 2 Kl. May, 7th year of his pontificate, [1250]. [With the bulla.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 54.

DIEULACRES (Abbey of). John, abbot of Dieulacres, and convent of the same grant to Richard [Plant?] of Stonycliff a licence to enclose about Lymgrene as much as to them pertains. Dated at Dieulacres in the feast of St. Thomas the apostle, 16 Hen. VI. [Partly illegible.] [With seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 55.

HORBOURNE. Thomas Fichet of Spraxton grants to Richard, son of sir Richard de Egebaston, kt., one messuage and carucate of land in Harbourne. Dated at Wef... the Saturday next after the feast of the Conversion of St. Paul, 22 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Staffs. 56.

Richard Cloddeshale of co. Warwick, esq., remits and quit-claims to Emma, who was the wife of sir Edward Doylle, kt., all right in a messuage and land which were sir Richard de Egebaston's, kt., in Horbourne. Dated at Coventry, 22 May, 3 Hen. V. Witn. John Weston, recorder of Coventry, etc. [With small fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 57.

Stafford. Master William, son of William Gunny, grants to John the baker ('pistori') of Stafford for 21s. certain land with the buildings &c. in Hungrey street, at an annual rent of 2d. (c. 1260-70.) [With seal.] Witn. William Bonamy and Richard Arnethion, "tunc prepositis Brug", etc. MS. Ch. Staffs. 58.

MORTON. Thomas Gifford, late of Chillington in the county of Stafford, esq., grants to Thomas Forster and Mary his wife the manor of Morton. Dated 29 April, 22 Hen. VIII. [With small seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 59.

An exemplification of a recovery, dated at Westminster, 14 June, 23 Hen. VIII, for passing the manor of Morton, with 6 messuages, 300 acres of land, 100 acres of meadow, 300 acres of pasture, 100 acres of wood, and 100 acres of underwood and furze, with appurtenances in Morton, to Thomas Forster, gent. [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 60.

WEDNESBURY. Adam de Hamwolde grants to Richard de Scrinklinge, son of Robert, and to Matilda his wife, and to John his eldest son for 17s. one half acre of land of his tenement of Hamwolde lying in the parish of Wednesberghe at Suthamwolde. Dated September, 9 Ed. [I]. [With broken seal.] MS. Ch. Staffs. 61.
SALISBURY (Diocese of). Letter of John, bp. of Sarum, to master George Wood, bachelor of decrees, for the collection of a subsidy within his diocese. Dated 14 April, 1496. MS. Ch. Wilts. 210.

John Stanley, esq., grants to David ap Monyn freysure one burgage lying between the burgage of Hugh Huls on the north, and a burgage of the said John on the south, for 24 years, at an annual rent of 6s. 8d. Dated at "Bleham", 14 October, 4 Ed. IV. MS. Ch. Misc. 211.
John, son of Thomas de Padusovere(?) of Wychio, grants to Joan his sister the whole of a tenement with appurtenances, at an annual rent of 3s. (c. 1290-1300) MS. Ch. Misc. 212.
Fragment of a charter dated 1131, Alexander being bishop [of Lincoln], by which Aelicia Euri ... appears to give to some church "Chatlendiam et duas acras de Inlandio ...". MS. Ch. Misc. 213.
Robert Moys grants to the lady Lucy Deros for 2s. an annual rent of 2d. (c. 1250-60) MS. Ch. Misc. 214.

Grant from Peter de Monte, apostolical prothoriotary and LL.D., nuncio in England, to William Byeerhaw and Joan his wife for their contribution towards the conversion of the Greeks to the Roman church and of them far off from Christianity, of licence to choose a confessor empowered to give plenary absolution. [The deed is mutilated at one side, and missing words have been supplied, and this note is written at the foot: "This was eaten after it was transcribed, and is now arn ended by the coppy."] [Endorsed with a form of absolution, partly effaced.] Dated 1440. MS. Ch. Misc. 215.

John Clements, rector of the church of Semere, grants to John Bukenham, clerk, piece of land &c. lying on the east of the grange of the rectory of Semere &c. for the sum of Â£31 10. 3 (with certain conditions) Dated at London the Monday next after the feast of St. Hilary, [2?] Ed. II. [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Misc. 216.

Letters patent of K. Hen. VI, dated at Westminster, 21 June, 30th of his reign, being a pardon granted to the prior and convent of St. Frideswide, Oxford [Mutilated and partly illegible.] MS. Ch. Misc. 217.

Robert de ... grants to Thurstan de Brailesham one ... of land in Todingeword, the latter giving to the grantor ... to his wife Milesentie 12d., and to his son and heir John sixpence. (c. 1220.) [Partly effaced.] MS. Ch. Misc. 218.
Probate of the will of Robert Lethom granted in October, 1480 at Knoll (in Kent), by archbishop Thomas Bourchier) to John Wetherley, executor. MS. Ch. Misc. 219.
Mutilated grant from William ... to Juliana Wai . . .of 2s. 6d. annual rent. Dated at ... 25 Ed. I. MS. Ch. Misc. 220.

Matillis, who was the wife of John le Smyth of Gosfeld, grants to Adam le Warremer of Aketon one messuage and six acres of arable land in [Gosfield]. Dated at Gosfeld the Monday next after ... 10 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Misc. 221.

WYKE. Robert de Burton grants to Muriel his sister the whole of his land which Christiana his mother gave to him in Wyke rendering to the King the service due from that land in the vill of Onleistune. [Mutilated.] (c. 1230.) MS. Ch. Misc. 222.
Cecilia, daughter of ... , grants to ... de Flecho seven acres cf land &c. in Rucumbe. [Fragment.] MS. Ch. Misc. 223.
A quit-claim by Am... to sir Simon Peche for money which was accustomed to be received of John Undeman, her brother. (c. 1260-70) [With fragment of seal.] MS. Ch. Misc. 224.

Fragment of pleadings in a recovery suit for land in Asshe, apparently by Edward Dileok versus William Shal...(?) tracing descent from families of Kaye and Kele; subsequent to royal letters of 20 June 14 Hen. VI for custody of the land of William Clyfford. 14 Ed. II. MS. Ch. Misc. 225.

Felicia, who was the wife of William monk (monachi), quitclaims to John de Henstesheia one acre of land above Torneye, and half an acre of meadow in the island, extending into Northhe, which John gave her in dowry on the part of his brother Henry; for this quit-claim the said John gave 9s. 4d. (c. 1230-40.) MS. Ch. Misc. 226.

Letters patent of King Edward III, dated at Westminster, 6 May, 51 of his reign, granted to John de Thornebury, extending to him the benefit of the general pardon passed in parliament, ono the quindene of Hilary, which is recited at lenght. [With seal.] MS. Ch. Misc. 227.

Acknowledgment of the receipt of Â£251 gold florins 10s. and 6d. of Roman money due to the papal Chamber from Otton de Danel, abbot of the Benedictine monastery of ... in the diocese of LiÃ©ge by George .... deputy chamberlain of pope Cal[ixti III]. Dated at Rome, 30 Jan., 1405. MS. Ch. Misc. 228.

Bond of Â£20 entered into by Roger Sharle alias Roger ... with Richard atte Helle of ... that he will have no communication by word or deed with Richard's wife or injure her good fame, or withdraw her from her husband. Dated on the feast of St. Gregory the pope, 10 Hen. VI. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Misc. 229.

John de [Bulwic?], chaplain, grants to Robert at Halle of Hastone one acre of land in the crofts of Hastone formerly belonging to Robert Howes. Dated at Wardon the Saturday next after the feast of St. Michael, 44 Ed. III. MS. Ch. Misc. 230.

Adam de Kyngesley grants to John del Lowe, son of Henry del Lowe, all the lands and tenements which he has in Senerley within the fee of Fulford and which he first had by gift of Alexander Hancokessone. Dated at Senerley the Friday next before the feast of St. Matthias, 21 Rich. II. MS. Ch. Misc. 231,

Reginald of the church grants to Richard le Ter one croft of land which lies between the land of the church viz. that which belongs to the vicarage, and the land of Robert, son of Robert the smith, which the said Reginald bought from Simon de Ecclesia; paying annually 8d. (c. 1220-30.) Witn. Towra, (sic) vicar, Ailred de Fuglesdene [etc.] Blackeman Lester. MS. Ch. Misc. 232.

Suffolk (?). Receipt by John Heydon for l00s., by the hands of John Bernard, in payment of rent due from Agnes, widow of ... Crane(?). Dated 20(?) February, 27 Hen. VI. [Slightly mutilated.] MS. Ch. Misc. 233.

John, son of Roger Avelin, grants to Thomas .... a certain part of his land in Bruttepor'(?); paying annually to Peter son of John Serle, the lord, 21 pence. Witn. Walter Wille and Thomas Sybrout(?) provosts, etc. for this donation the said Thomas gave 5s. 6d. sterling. MS. Ch. Misc. 234.

TERRIGGE? DURRIGGE?. Memorandum from the court roll of Durrigge (?), 11 June, 1 Hen. VIII, of the taking by William Harbarde from the lord of one messuage and one virgate of land late in the tenure of John Blysset. MS. Ch. Misc. 235.

Much mutilated and partially effaced exemplification by Stephen [Langton] archbishop of Canterbury of a papal grant concerning the privileges of the Premonstratentian order. [c. 1220] MS. Ch. Misc. 236.

William ... grants to Juliana Wall (?)2s. 6d. annual rent going out of her tenement del Oure (or Eure); and also of some other property, reserving an annual rent of 2s., for this she paid 7s. sterling. Dated on the feast of St. Lucy, virgin, 25 Ed. I. [Mutilated.] MS. Ch. Misc. 237.
ASTON ROWANT, OXON. CHALCFORD. Lease made 3 Ed. I, from Hugh de Chalcford to Hugh Pyrun, of a moor in Chalcford, in the parish of Estone, for six years, or the sum of four marks. MS. Ch. Misc. 238.

Brief of pope Gregory [XII] to the archdeacon of Bedford, on complaint from the Master Custos, and chaplains of the church of Northyevell, Lincoln diocese ordering excommunication of persons robbing the church of its possessions. Dated 12 Kl. June, 2nd year of his pontificate. MS. Ch. Misc. 239.

Certificate by Michiel le Poulletrer, keeper of the seal of bonds of the viscounty of Rouen, of a declaration made before John Gonel, notary, that John Wyth, an English esquire, was prisoner in the castle of Tremamsamme in Britany of a knight ... Mons. Morisse de Plusquollbare, where the deponent saw and spoke with him about three years before, and that he died a year and a half since, and that many knights and squires were present at his burial. Signed by ... Dated Sunday, 9 Dec., 1436. [French] MS. Ch. Misc. 240.
ANGLIA. Taxation for a subsidy collected from religious houses. [Temp. Hen. III.] [A large part effaced through damp.] Endorsed "Rotulus allocancium". MS. Rolls Eng. 1.
Fragment of a subsidy, leied on alien religious houses. [Temp. Ed. III.] MS. Rolls Eng. 2.

Long paper roll, containing officer copies, saec. xv exeunt., of (1) grant to the earls of Salesbury of 1000 marks annually from the exchequer; imperfect, (2) Inspeximus of grant by Alesia, widow of Thomas E. of Lancaster to Edw. II of various manors, etc. 9 July 16 Edw. II.
Inquisition of sir Rich. de Montacute, knt. from the Escheat Roll for Somerset, 8 Hen. VI post mortem of Thomas, earl of Salisbury. MS. Rolls Eng. 3.
Valor of the manors, lordships, lands, &c. of John, lord le Scrope, ending the feast of St. Michael, 32 Hen. VI. MS. Rolls Eng. 4.

DAVENTRY (Priory of). Fragment containing the beginning process between the prior and convent of Daventry and Stephen de Canaville, the rector of Mersh, in a suit concerning the tithes of Preston, an. 1315. [Mutilated and in part effaced.] MS. Rolls Northants. 10.
IRELAND. Payments upon the military list, an. 1662. MS. Rolls Ir. 2.
Rent Roll of the forfeited estate of Nicholas Browne, called Lord Viscount Kenmare, in Kerry, Cork, and Limerick, 1706. Signed by Jo. Asgill, 13 Feb. 1709/1710. MS. Rolls Ir. 3.
Descent of the Kings of England from William I to Charles I, an. 1625. MS. Pedigree Rolls 1.
Italian pedigree of Mary Queen of Scots from Robert III, King of Scotland, an. 1406, showing her title to the crown of England. MS. Pedigree Rolls 2.
Descent of Frederic V, King of Bohemia, and Elizabeth his wife, daughter of King James I of England, with Arms in colour. 1619. MS. Pedigree Rolls 3.
Descent of Thomas, visc. Beaumont [of Swords] from Henry, duke of Lancaster, and Henry de Beaumont, with numerous coats of their Arms in colour. 30 Edw. I (1302) MS. Pedigree Rolls 4.
Pedigree of the family of BENDLOW (or Bendeowes), Yorkshire, with all the coats of arms; from 7 Henry I to temp. Chas. I MS. Pedigree Rolls 5.

Roll containing the descent and alliances of the families of BRUS, FAUCONHERG, PERCEHAY, SAXTON, and DARCY (late 17th century); written on the reverse of a roll of the Account of Edmund Hesham and John Fissher, collectors of the rents and keeper of the Bridge of Fosse [at York], 2 Feb. 25 to 2 Feb. 26 Hen. VI. MS. Pedigree Rolls 6.
Pedigree showing the descent of Q. Elizabeth from the family of BUTLER, earls of Ormond, with collateral branches. [Temp. Eliz.] MS. Pedigree Rolls 7.
Pedigree showing four descents of the family of CASTILLION, of Berkshire, from 1597, with Arms in colours. MS. Pedigree Rolls 8.
Pedigrees of the families of CHICHELET, CAREW, KEDERMINISTER, and Hoo, to an. 1620, from the books in the office of arms, with Arms in colours. MS. Pedigree Rolls 9.
Very long pedigree of the family of CONYERS, Yorkshire, ending about 1739. [Mutilated at the end.] Very many coats of arms in colours. [Paper] MS. Pedigree Rolls 10.
Pedigree of COOKE of Barnstaple, 1580-1817. MS. Pedigree Rolls 11.
Descent of the family of HATLEY, from 1480 to beginning of 18th century. MS. Pedigree Rolls 12.
Pedigree of the family of HAGGERD of Derbyshire and Cambridgeshire, for 15 generations, to 1603, with all the cont. of arms in ... attested by W. Camden. MS. Pedigree Rolls 13.

The pedegree of Back HOLLOWAY of London, lineally descended from Thomas Holloway of Aveley, in Shropsheire, who came forth of the auncient family of Holloway, of Holloway in the co. of Devon. [c. 1800] Coats of arms in colours. MS. Pedigree Rolls 14.

Very finely written pedigree of the family of I'ANSON of Yorkshire, collected by Geo. Owen, York, herald and attested by Hen. St George. (L'Anson) Witnessed by Arthur C. Creshild, notary public, and endorsed with a certificate in Spanish by don Alonso de Cardenas, ambassador in England, 8 Dec. 1642. four generations only. Coats of arms in colours. Dated 26 Nov., 1642. [Latin and Spanish] MS. Pedigree Rolls 15.
Descents of the families of JONES of Chilton and STOKES of London, from Salop, from King Ed. I to Jan. 10, 1876. MS. Pedigree Rolls 16.
Descent of the families of KING and VOAR to BOTFIELD. [c. 1810-20?] MS. Pedigree Rolls 17.
Pedigree of the family of LLOWARCH alias FLOWER of Monmouthshire for five generations. Attested at the office of arms 6 Aug. 1657. MS. Pedigree Rolls 18.

Pedigree of JEVAN LLOYD of the Vayrdre, gentleman, for eleven generations, set forth by Lewis James, gent. of Llangeler, and drawn by John Moythey of Slanbeder ..., with all the coats of arms in colour. April, 1614. MS. Pedigree Rolls 19.
Descent of the family of LLOYD, from Roderick Mawr, ending at David Lloyd, esq., ad. 1701, with all the coats of Arms in colours. MS. Pedigree Rolls 20.
Pedigree of the family of LOVELL, from the time of Henry I. 26 Sept., 1576, with all the coats of arms in colours. Endorsed in the office of arms. MS. Pedigree Rolls 21.
Pedigree of the family of NORWICHE, with Arms in trick. Temp. Eliz. [On paper] MS. Pedigree Rolls 22.
Pedigree of Morgan POWELL of Pembroke. ... by Thomas Jones, 1629(?) Coats of arms in colours. [On paper] MS. Pedigree Rolls 23.
Pedigree of the family of RALEIGH, with coats of Arms in colours. Temp. Eliz. MS. Pedigree Rolls 24.
Short pedigree of SHELDON of Beoly, Worcester, for four generations. MS. Pedigree Rolls 25.
Copy of a pedigree of William lord SHERARD of Stapleford, co. Leic., made 1633 and testified by sir William Segar, kt., Garter, continued to 1781. MS. Pedigree Rolls 26.
Pedigree of the family of TRAVELL of Wenlock, bought ... to John, son of John Fravell, of London, merchant, made an. 1654. MS. Pedigree Rolls 27.
Pedigree for seven generations of the family of WHITAKER, with all the Arms in colours, signed by Robert Cook, Clarencieux. MS. Pedigree Rolls 28.
Pedigree of the family of WHITEHALL, Staffordshire, from the time of Henry IV to 1663 by sir W. Dugdale. Arms in trick. MS. Pedigree Rolls 29.
Pedigree of sir HENRY WILLIAMS, knt., from 10th century, gathered by R. P., gent. Oct. 1, 1616. Coats of arms in colours. MS. Pedigree Rolls 30.
